catalogueDesc.name: ENDPOINT_HGV
catalogueDesc.label: ENDPOINT_HGV
catalogueDesc.scopeNote: Catalogue which contains toxicological endpoints and health based guidance values for chemical risk assessment

termDesc.termScopeNote: Not in the Compendium v10 - only to be used for records created from original botanical compendium

termDesc.termExtendedName: Tumor dose: intake associated with a 5 % excess incidence of tumours in experimental studies in animals.
Dietary dose producing lethality in 50% of experimental organisms
No observed adverse effect daily dose
Effect concentration 15% organisms show adverse effect
Effect concentration 10% organisms show adverse effect
Effect concentration 50% organisms show adverse effect
Effective application rate 50% organisms show adverse effect
termDesc.termScopeNote: Effective application rate that results in an undesirable change or alteration of 50% in the test endpoint being measured relative to the control (http://www.oecd.org/chemicalsafety/testing/33653757.pdf)

termDesc.termExtendedName: Concentration producing lethality in 10% of experimental organisms
Concentration producing lethality in 50% of experimental organisms
Dose producing lethality in 50% of experimental organisms
Lethal dose rate in 50% of experimental organisms
Threshold of Toxicological Concern Cramer Class I
Threshold of Toxicological Concern Cramer Class II
Threshold of Toxicological Concern Cramer Class III
Effect concentration 5% organisms show adverse effect
Effect concentration 25% organisms show adverse effect
Effective loading rate lethal to 50% of experimental organisms
25% increase in incidence of a specific tumour above background incidence in the lifespan of the species
Effective concentration to 20% of test organisms
Concentration at or below which no ecologically adverse effects would be expected
termDesc.termScopeNote: The concept of an Ecologically Acceptable Concentration (EAC) was introduced to assess the environmental risks of pesticides under European Directive 91/414/EEC. EAC is a concentration at which no "unacceptable" ecological effects occur and has been interpreted as a concentration at which "acceptable" effects may be allowed to occur.

termDesc.termExtendedName: Dose required to achieve 50% of the desired response in 50% of the population (Median effective dose)
Dose producing lethality in 100% of experimental organisms
Amount of drug required to induce mortality

termDesc.termScopeNote: Level of (nutrient) intake estimated to satisfy the physiological requirement or metabolic demand, as defined by the specified criterion for adequacy for that nutrient, in half of the people in a population group, given a normal distribution of requirement.

Level of (nutrient) intake that is adequate for virtually all people in a population group. On the assumption that the individual requirements for a nutrient are normally distributed within a population and the inter-individual variation is known, the PRI is calculated on the basis of the AR plus twice its standard deviation (SD). This will meet the requirements of 97.5% of the individuals in the population.

termDesc.termExtendedName: Benchmark Dose associated with a specified change (i.e. 5%)
termDesc.termScopeNote: Dose level, estimated from the fitted dose-response curve, associated with a specified change (i.e. 5%) doi: 10.2903/j.efsa.2017.4658
